title: Do autistic and neurotypical people fall into each other's 'uncanny valley'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hmm, that’s an interesting perspective. Yes, it does seem that autistic tendencies might precisely trigger the “uncanny valley” response, as proposed design principles for robotics confirm: “Reducing conflict and uncertainty by matching appearance, behavior, and ability. In terms of performance, if a robot looks too appliance-like, people expect little from it; if it looks too human, people expect too much from it. A highly human-like appearance leads to an expectation that certain behaviors are present, such as humanlike motion dynamics. This likely operates at a sub-conscious level and may have a biological basis. Neuroscientists have noted "when the brain's expectations are not met, the brain...generates a 'prediction error'. As human-like artificial agents become more commonplace, perhaps our perceptual systems will be re-tuned to accommodate these new social partners. Or perhaps, we will decide "it is not a good idea to make [robots] so clearly in our image after all."(emphasis added). The “mind-blindness” and “theory of mind” explanations of autism (flawed in their uni-lateral understanding), are predicated on the differing norms of reactions and usage of behavior to convey information, and the ensuing breakdown in non-verbal communication. This effect is perhaps why sci-fi has made so much mileage out of ‘autistic-esque’ characters as alien (Spock, Data, C3-P0, Marvin). My personal experience further confirms confirms the general concept: socially isolated families tend to develop their own idiosyncrasies that strike the outside observer as “odd” or “uncanny” (ie: the “Brown family accent”). I have also had issues with particular people mistaking nervousness for deception, based (I have to suppose) on this effect.

I’m on the autistic side - and I do not find neurotypical people to be “uncanny”. That’s probably just because only about 1% of people are autistic - so 99% of the people I know and have grown up with were “neurotypical”. The reverse is harder to judge - but I’m fairly sure that autistic people do seem decidedly “odd” to neurotypicals - and in truth, when I meet other autistic people, I often find them to be weird, even though I know that I may be being judged the same way! I’m not entirely sure this is truly an “uncanny valley” effect though…that idea is that when something isn’t remotely human (like a cartoon character) - then there is no feeling of weirdness - but when something comes CLOSE to being human (like an android robot), it actually seems weirder/creepier than a cartoon character. That said - I’m also left-handed, and many right handed people find it REALLY strange to watch me do things like using wood-working tools or something. My father (who was right handed) always remarked on how he found it hard to watch me using tools to fix problems around the house because I always seemed to be using them wrong. But for sure, I don’t find neurotypical people to be particularly weird - so if there is an effect, it’s in one direction only.

To lend weight to other, better, answers I shall add my own experience. My partner tells me that I am an 'uncanny valley person' in that I appear mostly human but am not totally. Bear in mind they aren't being insulting in calling me not human, they are merely trying to explain the reaction that they, and others, have to me. The response is very much reminiscent of 'uncanny valley' from people that take an instant... opposite of instant connection to me. People fall into two main camps - they either decide that I am a great person to know, full of boundless energy and great to get to know further or they decide that I am, well, in the 'uncanny valley'. Sometimes they will switch camps based on experience and meeting me more than once. My partner switched camps, toward 'uncanny valley' and, increasingly, finds me difficult to be around in any way. For what that experience is worth. On the reverse, no, I do not find NTs (or people without ASD) in the 'uncanny valley'. Like others have suggested, finding other people as not being people is... well, uncomfortably close to what I study and teach: History. When that happens there are... consequences.

This is a matter of appearances, where perception of the Other arouses a feeling of revulsion, that apparently varying between less or more. I would say it is a learned reaction, not one necessarily a hard-wired emotion, but subjective; we — NT and ASD — are not robots ourselves, nor are our reactions to each other one I would place in that valley without considering the persons involved. It seems to exist in NT’s regarding variously injured, wounded, disabled or disfigured humans, NT or not, and some are even repelled by prostheses that make a meaningful participation in society possible. The term was first coined in 1970 by Japanese roboticist Masahiro Mori in an essay that received little attention at the time, but has since exploded in popularity and relevance. He hypothesized that “a person’s response to a humanlike robot would abruptly shift from empathy to revulsion as it approached, but failed to attain, a lifelike appearance.” (E.N. on orig. translation, MacDorman & Kageki 2012). The Uncanny Valley From the autism side — mine — I am in old age apparently able to deal with that Valley as well as NT’s, and perhaps better than most, lending some credence to the learned reaction hypothesis, but DEATH is at its bottom, and I still can’t remember what the bodies looked like I saw delivered below our control tower at Phu Loi. PTSD is not, however, a reaction foreign to either ASD or NT.

‘We really can’t be mistaken for replicas, even by NTs.’ I don't think that the OP is suggesting that we may be mistaken for replicas, but rather that we may trigger the response of eeriness or revulsion because we are almost like NTs, but not quite. Although the phrase was originally applied to androids/robots and humans, I have seen it used in other contexts. Some people do seem to find some other human beings uncanny, eerie, odd, or disturbing in either appearance or behaviour, and are creeped out by it. This isn't restricted to autistics, but includes amputees, people who are badly burned or scarred, people who are blind, conjoined twins, people with various mental illnesses, and many others. However, I would argue that this seems a human response rather than an NT response .. and I suspect may even apply beyond humanity to other animal species, where Otherness or difference leads to being rejected or cast out. It's a hopeful sign, though, that we (humans) can often be trained not to react that way. And, indeed, not all of us feel that way in the first place.

A2A. Uncanny valley is a hypothesis that human replicas that appear almost, but not exactly, like real human beings elicit feelings of eeriness and revulsion among some observers. Uncanny Valley (disambiguation) - Wikipedia I’m not a neurotypical, so I can’t answer definitively, even for myself. But this sounds pretty far-fetched, stretching the hypothesis from humanoid androids to real, warm-blooded, people. We really can’t be mistaken for replicas, even by NTs. So NO, to the Question.

No clue what an uncanny valley is. Please provide a link or explanation. But odds are the answer is yes that some individuals with autism will do something that NT people do, just as some NT people do things that individuals with autism do.
No. They're both real humans. Also, there's nothing revolting about the appearance of neurotypicals or autistic people for each other since they look the same.
